bestBHT.bht: Paul admits that his boasting may seem foolish and not in keeping with the example of the Lord Jesus, but he clarifies that it was permitted by the Spirit to draw the Corinthians away from their false teachers. While he acknowledges that his conduct might not align with the meekness and gentleness of Christ, Paul explains that circumstances have compelled him to boast in order to assert his apostolic authority. Ultimately, his aim is to challenge the Corinthians' misguided boasting and to open their eyes to the truth.

Henry Alford: Proceeding on the terms, as a fool, he disclaims for this self-boasting the character of inspiration—or of being said in pursuance of his mission from the Lord."
After the (mind of the) Lord, in pursuance, i.e. in this case, of inspiration from above: not as in 1 Cor. vii. 10, 25, 40."
As it were in foolishness, i.e. 'putting myself into the situation, and speaking the words of a foolish man vaunting of himself.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Even this boasting, though undesirable in itself, was permitted by the Spirit, taking into account its aim, namely, to draw off the Corinthians from their false teachers to the apostle.
It merely guards against his boasting being made a justification of boasting in general, which is not ordinarily 'after the Lord,' that is, consistent with Christian humility.
Albert Barnes: I do not speak this imitating the example of the Lord Jesus or strictly as becomes his follower.

But circumstances have compelled me and much as I would prefer another strain at remark, and sensible as I am in general of the folly of boasting, yet a regard to my apostolic office and authority urges me to this course.

Paul admitted that what he said was not in exact accordance with the spirit of the Lord Jesus; and in admitting this he designed probably to administer a delicate hint that all their boasting was a wide departure from that spirit.
John Calvin: What I speak, I speak not after the Lord His disposition, it is true, had an eye to God, but the outward appearance might seem unsuitable to a servant of the Lord.
At the same time, the things that Paul confesses respecting himself, he, on the other hand, condemns in the false Apostles.
He transfers to his own person what belonged to them, that he may thus open the eyes of the Corinthians.
Archibald T. Robertson: Not after the Lord (ου κατα Κυριον). Not after the example of the Lord.
He had appealed to the example of Christ in 2 Corinthians 10:1 (the meekness and gentleness of Christ).
Paul's conduct here, he admits, is not in keeping with that. But circumstances force him on.
John Gill: he did not then speak as an apostle, or one sent by Christ
he took that of a fool upon him, that he might speak the more freely
he spoke not as according to the commandment, or example of his Lord; or according to the Spirit of the Lord, or his own Spirit, as renewed by his grace
John Wesley: I speak not after the Lord — Not by an express command from him; though still under the direction of his Spirit.
But as it were foolishly — In such a manner as many may think foolish.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul admits that his boasting might seem foolish and not in keeping with the example of the Lord Jesus, as he disclaims any divine inspiration for this self-boasting. However, he clarifies that while his boasting may appear unsuitable, it was permitted by the Spirit in order to draw the Corinthians away from their false teachers and towards him as the true apostle. Although Paul acknowledges that his conduct might not align with the meekness and gentleness of Christ, he explains that circumstances have compelled him to boast in order to assert his apostolic authority. Ultimately, Paul's aim is to challenge the Corinthians' misguided boasting and to open their eyes to the truth.

Paul admits that his boasting may seem foolish and not in keeping with the example of the Lord Jesus, but he clarifies that it was permitted by the Spirit to draw the Corinthians away from their false teachers. While he acknowledges that his conduct might not align with the meekness and gentleness of Christ, Paul explains that circumstances have compelled him to boast in order to assert his apostolic authority. Ultimately, his aim is to challenge the Corinthians' misguided boasting and to open their eyes to the truth.

Paul's self-boasting may appear foolish and not in accordance with the example of Christ, but he makes it clear that it was permitted by the Spirit to redirect the Corinthians from their false teachers. Despite admitting that his behavior does not align with Christ's meekness and gentleness, Paul claims that circumstances have compelled him to boast in order to assert his apostolic authority. Ultimately, his intention is to challenge the Corinthians' misguided boasting and lead them to the truth.

Paul's self-boasting, though appearing foolish and not in line with Christ's example, is permitted by the Spirit to redirect the Corinthians from their false teachers. While he admits that his behavior doesn't align with the meekness and gentleness of Christ, he asserts that circumstances have forced him to boast in order to establish his apostolic authority. The goal of his boasting is to challenge the Corinthians' misguided pride and guide them towards the truth.

Paul acknowledges that his self-boasting may seem foolish, not in keeping with the Lord's example, and not consistent with Christian humility. Yet, he explains that the Spirit permitted this boasting to draw the Corinthians away from their false teachers and towards him as the true apostle. Although his conduct may not align with Jesus' meekness and gentleness, Paul's aim is to challenge the Corinthians' misguided boasting and lead them to the truth. Ultimately, he hopes to open their eyes to the true nature of his apostolic authority.
